posts.cooked: Has anything been done on this? I need to update from Win 10 to Win 11 and I can‚Äôt believe I am about to loose 3+ years of message history (which I look at almost daily) because Signal hasn‚Äôt bothered to create a feature for this. Seriously making me reconsider my choice of messaging program.

link_counts.title: Signal Desktop: backup / restore messages and media

posts.cooked:
cweinhofer:

I am about to loose 3+ years of message history

You‚Äôre not. Moving to a new computer or restoring after a system wipe/clean install with the desktop app is as simple as copying a single folder (the Signal data folder).

On Windows 10, that folder is C:\Users\<YourName>\AppData\Roaming\Signal. Simply make a backup of that folder, do your system upgrade, reinstall Signal, then copy your backed up folder back in to place.

For completeness, the full list of folders for supported operating systems are:

macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Signal
Linux: ~/.config/Signal
Windows 10: C:\Users\<YourName>\AppData\Roaming\Signal

They can all be used to backup/restore/transfer your Signal Desktop data in the same way.

link_counts.title: Message history sync for newly linked (Desktop and iPad) devices
Message history sync for newly linked (Desktop and iPad) devices

posts.cooked:
Thanks, @Herohtar Appreciate you chiming in with this. I had seen that on an ‚Äúunofficial‚Äù site with Signal info, but was a little hesitant since Signal‚Äôs official line is that you can‚Äôt transfer data between devices.

Screenshot 2023-06-30 at 13-24-23 Backup and Restore Messages709√ó204 5.42 KB

https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/360007059752-Backup-and-Restore-Messages#desktop_restore

Just curious, if it‚Äôs that easy, why does Signal act like it can‚Äôt be done? Are they trying to discourage people from using the desktop client? I switched phones a few months back and there was plenty of support for that.

It‚Äôs probably because it requires a bit of technical skill and knowledge of your OS, which a lot of people don‚Äôt have. (eg, AppData is a hidden folder on Windows) And it can cause problems if not done correctly (eg, someone might assume they could use it to set up a new computer with all their message history and keep the old one, but since it clones the device id, that won‚Äôt work).

By the time you start explaining all the technical details and pointing out all the ‚Äúgotchas‚Äù, it gets really complex.

As someone in IT support myself, I can certainly appreciate difficulty. But flat out telling users that they can‚Äôt do something that is actually fairly simple to do (if you have the technical knowledge), seems like a wrongheaded approach.

Why not just say ‚ÄúThis is possible, but it should only be attempted by advanced users. We can‚Äôt provide support if you get into trouble, but here are some basic steps and a few caveots.‚Äù

And speaking of that, here‚Äôs the link to a more detailed tutorial that was in the previous thread for this topic in case anyone needs it:

Signal Wiki ‚Äì 30 May 23

How to move Signal Desktop message history to another computer (or during an...

.

link_counts.title: How to move Signal Desktop message history to another computer (or during an OS reinstall) - Signal Wiki

posts.cooked:
Don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs too late to add a question here?

I‚Äôm going to try the method of moving ~/.config/Signal to another device to see if I can get Signal to use it. One biggish wrinkle is that my hope is to do that on a GrapheneOS Pixel.

My current problem is that I can‚Äôt figure out a command line way to do that.

If I use a GUI file manager (eg dolphin) I can copy just fine, but it changes all the time stamps etc. I need something like cp -a. But‚Ä¶

I can‚Äôt figure out the sftp command to copy to the Pixel. The Pixel says it‚Äôs visible as ‚ÄúPixel 6a‚Äù but $sftp cp -a /home/me/.config/Signal Pixel\ 6a/Internal\ Storage/ gets nowhere of course.

There‚Äôs an endless /dev/lots-of-alphanumerics name visible in the dolphin location field when its showing Pixel dirs. Is there something I could be doing with that?

I‚Äôd be super-grateful if a wise soul could tell me what command I could try to transfer files with permissions and time stamps intact!

This is for Signal Desktop, not Android, if you can run Signal Desktop on a Pixel, then I think something might be wrong.

On Android use the backup feature of Signal
Is there no way to built this feature in ? Or copy the backup feature from Android to the Desktop Signal ? Is this planned on a roadmap ?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
They‚Äôve been working on it for a few years:

Encrypted cloud backups Feature Requests
This would be great feature that can be implement with schedule backup. ex: backup every 30/60/90/180/etc and keep the most X number of backups. this way we can restore if ever needed

There‚Äôs been a ton of work in the last six months including front-end navigation so hopefully it‚Äôll hit beta soon.

Well I didn‚Äôt see much announcement or any transparency about this efforts that was shared in this post or on the GitHub issue sadly so before you comment I couldn‚Äôt find this information easily. Unless I read all the commits on every branch maybe. @Avitus

Also Cloud Backups is not what I‚Äôm requesting btw. But just local backup would be cool.

posts.name: David Bogner
posts.cooked: As of August 3, 2024 the marked solution Backup/Restore/Transfer Desktop history - #2 by Herohtar does not work anymore and results in a database error.

It changed because now the database is encrypted and the key is stored more securely.

Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)? General Discussion
If you need to move data between computers, the encrypted key can be temporarily decrypted if you run this code in Electron Fiddle: const { app, safeStorage } = require('electron'); const { join } = require('node:path'); const { readFileSync, writeFileSync } = require('node:fs'); const folder = join(app.getPath('appData'), 'Signal'); app.setPath('userData', folder); app.setName('Signal'); app.on('ready', () => { const configPath = join(folder, 'config.json'); const json = readFileSync(co‚Ä¶

link_counts.title: Signal stores encryption key in plain text on desktop client(s)?

posts.name: David Bogner
posts.cooked:
I am trying to follow the new procedure. I could now do the following:
‚Üí Find the Signal key in GNOME keyring
‚Üí decrypt the encrypted key in config.json

But the next steps are not yet clear. So I decided to keep my old computer and wait with the transfer of the data until there is a solution available. Loosing the history would be quite a pain.

@Herohtar, do you know if the developers have any plans to fix the error that is now happening ‚Äì and thus killing off any possibility of moving between devices.

Our company has used Signal for a few years, but if this is a signal (pardon the pun) of the developers disregard for data portability, then continuing to use Signal in contexts where message history is important is a non-starter.

I‚Äôm currently investigating different Matrix-based solutions, but havn‚Äôt found any that we‚Äôre 100% pleased with. They‚Äôre not as polished as Signal, but at least your data isn‚Äôt imprisoned.

Signal is developing a backup/sync feature that from what I understand looks like it will automatically sync some amount of chat history to newly linked desktop clients, so there will be no need to copy data folders in the future.
A post was split to a new topic: Remove chats when logging out

I have only been occasionally following the backup feature - do we know if it will allow for a machine-readable and/or text+attachment export of the Signal data? Being able to a) move from a broken system to a new system, and b) access the data outside of Signal, are both crucially important for me.

posts.name: Marko
posts.cooked:
If you are a Linux user, you can use the script below to sync signal-desktop across desktops. To use the script you need rclone and Google Drive. Do not use the script if you do not understand it. Make a backup of your Signal folder first.

#!/bin/bash
#===============================================================================
#
#          FILE: sync_signal_with_gdrive.sh
#
#         USAGE: ./sync_signal_with_gdrive.sh
#
#   DESCRIPTION: 
#
#       OPTIONS: ---
#  REQUIREMENTS: ---
#          BUGS: ---
#         NOTES: ---
#        AUTHOR: <Your Name and email>
#  ORGANIZATION: IT
#       CREATED: 29/02/2024 14:43:15
#      REVISION: 1 
#===============================================================================

#===============================================================================
#     General Script Settings
#===============================================================================

set -o errexit    # Exit if any error occurs
set -o pipefail   # The exit status external commad that threw a non-zero
#                 # exit code is returned
set -o nounset    # Exit if variable is not declared
# set -o xtrace   # Debug showing execution line by line

#===============================================================================
#     Default Variables for File and Directory
#===============================================================================

THISDIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
THISFILEPATH="${THISDIR}/$(basename "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")"
THISFILE="$(basename ${THISFILEPATH})"
BASENAME="$(basename ${THISFILEPATH} .sh)"
BASEDIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${THISDIR}")" && pwd)" # <-- change this to yours

#===============================================================================
#     Colors
#===============================================================================

N="\e[0m"     # Clear formatting
B="\e[1m"     # Bold
R="\e[31m"    # Red
G="\e[32m"    # Green
Y="\e[33m"    # Yellow
C="\e[36m"    # Cyan
WARN="[${Y}WARNING${N}]"  # Yellow Warning
ERR="[${R}ERROR${N}]"     # Red Error
OK="[${G}OK${N}]"         # Green Ok

#===============================================================================
#       Check Dependencies
#===============================================================================

if ! command -v rclone &> /dev/null
then
    echo -e "\n${ERR} ${Y}rclone ${G} could not be found, please install it ${N}\n"
    exit 1
fi


#===============================================================================
#       Script Start
#===============================================================================
# Undeclared variables can be defined with:
#arg1="${1:-}"

MYUSERNAME=$(whoami)

# If you have a Google Workspace account create a service account to store the Signal directory
# Note a separate config file for this
GDRIVE="<your Google Drive name in rclone>"
GDIR=/Signal
RCLONECONFIG=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/.config/rclone/rclone-signal.conf
RCLONEJSON=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/.config/rclone/rclone-xxxxx-yyyyyyyyyy.json



# If you use just your gmail account uncomment the following
# and create the appropriate directories
#GDRIVE="<your Google Drive name in rclone>"
#GDIR=/Backups/Signal-Desktop/.config/Signal
#RCLONECONFIG=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/.config/rclone/rclone.conf

# Standard config on Linux 
CONFIGDIR=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/.config
LOCALDIR=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/.config/Signal
GDRIVEDIR=${GDRIVE}:${GDIR}
LOGFILE=/tmp/rclone.log
GDMOUNT=/home/${MYUSERNAME}/GDSignal		# This directory must exist and be empty

# Verify if Dirs are different
# If remote is newer then sync GD -> Local 
# If local is newer then run Local -> GD 
# On Signal exit do a final sync 
#
TIMESTAMP=$(date +%s)

mount_gdrive () {
	if mountpoint -q ${GDMOUNT}
	then
		echo -e "\n${OK} ${Y}${GDRIVE} ${G}is already mounted ${N}"
	  echo -e "\n${OK} ${G}To unmount: ${Y}fusermount -u ${GDMOUNT} ${N}\n"
	else
	   echo -e "\n${G}Mounting ${Y}${GDMOUNT}${N}\n"
	   rclone --config ${RCLONECONFIG} mount ${GDRIVEDIR} ${GDMOUNT} --vfs-cache-mode full --file-perms 744 --daemon
	  echo -e "\n${OK} ${G}To unmount: ${Y}fusermount -u ${GDMOUNT} ${N}\n"
	fi
}

unmount_gdrive () {
	if mountpoint -q ${GDMOUNT}
	then
		echo -e "\n${OK} ${Y}${GDRIVE} ${G}is mounted, unmounting ${N}"
	  echo -e "\n${OK} ${G}To unmount: ${Y}fusermount -u ${GDMOUNT} ${N}\n"
		umount ${GDMOUNT}
	else
		echo -e "\n${WARN} ${Y}${GDRIVE} ${G}is not mounted, nothing to do ${N}"
	fi
}

compare_datestamp_and_sync () {
		if [ -d ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp ]
		then
			echo -e "\n${WARN}${G} .timestamp has mutated into a directory, fixing...${N}\n"
			cp ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp/.timestamp /tmp/
			rm -rf ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
			cp /tmp/.timestamp ${LOCALDIR}/
		fi
  if [ -f ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp ]
  then
    TIMESTAMP_GDRIVE=$(cat ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp)
    echo -e "\n${G} Timestamp on GDrive is ${Y}${TIMESTAMP_GDRIVE}${N}\n"
  else
    echo -e "\n${WARN} ${G}The file ${Y}${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp${G} does not exist! ${N}"
    echo -e "\n${G} Doing first sync, it will take some time... please wait${N}\n"
    date +%s > ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp
    TIMESTAMP_GDRIVE=$(cat ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp)
  fi

	sleep 1

	if [ -f ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp ]
	then
		TIMESTAMP_LOCAL=$(cat ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp)
    echo -e "\n${G} Timestamp on Local is ${Y}${TIMESTAMP_LOCAL}${N}\n"
	else
    echo -e "\n${WARN} ${G}The file ${Y}${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp${G} does not exist! ${N}"
    echo -e "\n${G} Assuming GDrive is newer${N}\n"
		#TIMESTAMP_LOCAL=$(($(cat ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp) - 1))
		let TIMESTAMP_LOCAL="$(cat ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp) - 1"
	fi

	DIFFTIME=$((${TIMESTAMP_LOCAL}-${TIMESTAMP_GDRIVE}))
	if ((${DIFFTIME} == 0))
	then
		echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Remote an local are identical, nothing to sync${N}\n"
	elif ((${DIFFTIME} > 0))
	then
		echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Local is newer, sycing to remote${N}\n"
		if  rclone --config ${RCLONECONFIG} sync --fast-list --transfers=32 --checkers=16 --tpslimit=9 --drive-chunk-size=128M ${LOCALDIR}/ ${GDRIVEDIR}/ --stats-one-line -P --stats 2s
		then
			echo -e "\n${G} Updating remote timestamp to ${Y}${TIMESTAMP_LOCAL}${N}\n"
			rm ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp
			rclone --config ${RCLONECONFIG} copy ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp ${GDRIVEDIR}/
			#cp ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp
			echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Sync finished${N}"
			sleep 5
		else
			echo -e "\n${ERR}${G} Sync failed${N}"
			exit 1
		fi
	elif ((${DIFFTIME} < 0))
	then
		echo -e "\n${OK}${G} GDrive is newer, sycing to local${N}\n"
		if  rclone --config ${RCLONECONFIG} sync --fast-list --transfers=32 --checkers=16 --tpslimit=9 --drive-chunk-size=128M ${GDRIVEDIR}/ ${LOCALDIR}/ --stats-one-line -P --stats 2s
		then
			echo -e "\n${G} Updating local timestamp to ${Y}${TIMESTAMP_GDRIVE}${N}\n"
			rm ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
			rclone --config ${RCLONECONFIG} copy ${GDRIVEDIR}/.timestamp ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
			#cp ${GDMOUNT}/.timestamp ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
			echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Sync finished${N}"
			sleep 5
		else
			echo -e "\n${ERR}${G} Sync failed${N}"
			exit 1
		fi
	fi
}

backup_local_signal () {
	DATESTAMP=$(date "+%y%m%d%H%M%S")
	echo -e "\n${G} Backing up Signal to ${Y}Signal-${DATESTAMP}.tgz${N}"
	tar cf - ${LOCALDIR} -P | pv -s $(du -sb ${LOCALDIR} | awk '{print $1}') | gzip > ${CONFIGDIR}/Signal-${DATESTAMP}.tgz
}

run_signal () {
	if pgrep -x "signal-desktop" > /dev/null
	then
		echo -e "\n${ERR}${Y} signal-desktop${G} is already runnig${N}"
		echo -e "\n${G} Please close it before running this script${N}\n"
		sleep 5
		exit 1
	else
		echo -e "\n${G}Running ${Y}Signal Desktop${N}"
		echo -e "\n${WARN}${G} Please do not exit this script after closing Signal (it will run another sync)${N}\n"
		if [ $(stat -c "%a" /opt/Signal/chrome-sandbox) == "4755" ]
		then
			signal-desktop --password-store="basic" $@ >/dev/null
		else
			echo -e "\n${WARN} ${G}The file ${Y}/opt/Signal/chrome-sandbox${G} has wrong permission${N}"
			echo -e "${G}Please give sudo password to change it ${N}"
			sudo chmod 4755 /opt/Signal/chrome-sandbox
			signal-desktop --password-store="basic" $@ >/dev/null
		fi
		CURRENT_VERSION=$(apt-get -s install signal-desktop | grep version | sed -e 's/^.*(//' -e 's/).*//' | head -1) && true
		echo "${CURRENT_VERSION}" > ${LOCALDIR}/.version
		echo "${CURRENT_VERSION}" > ${GDMOUNT}/.version
		if [ -d ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp ]
		then
			echo -e "\n${WARN}${G} .timestamp has mutated into a directory, fixing...${N}\n"
			cp ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp/.timestamp /tmp/
			rm -rf ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
		fi
		date +%s > ${LOCALDIR}/.timestamp
	fi
}

check_for_upgrade () {
	APP=signal-desktop
	GIT_VERSION=$(curl --silent  https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Desktop/tags/ | grep Signal-Desktop | grep -v beta | grep h2 | sed -e 's/^.*tag\///' -e 's/".*//' -e s'/v//' | head -1)
	CURRENT_VERSION=$(apt-get -s install signal-desktop | grep version | sed -e 's/^.*(//' -e 's/).*//' | head -1) && true
	LOCAL_VERSION="Unknown"
	GDRIVE_VERSION="Unknown"
	if [ -f ${LOCALDIR}/.version ]
  then
		LOCAL_VERSION=$(cat ${LOCALDIR}/.version)
		if [ -f ${GDMOUNT}/.version ]
		then
			GDRIVE_VERSION=$(cat ${GDMOUNT}/.version)
			echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Local version: ${Y}${LOCAL_VERSION} ${G}, GDrive version: ${Y}${GDRIVE_VERSION}${G}, Git version: ${Y}${GIT_VERSION}${N}"
			echo -e "\n${OK}${G} Installed version: ${Y}${CURRENT_VERSION} ${N}"
		fi
  else
    echo -e "\n${WARN} ${G}The file ${Y}${LOCALDIR}/.version${G} does not exist! ${N}"
  fi
	if [ "$GDRIVE_VERSION" != "$LOCAL_VERSION" ]
	then
		echo -e "\n${WARN}${G} Local version ${Y}${LOCAL_VERSION} ${G}differ from GDrive version ${Y}${GDRIVE_VERSION}${N}"
	fi
	#if [ $? == 0 ]
	if [ "$GIT_VERSION" != "$CURRENT_VERSION" ]
	then
		#NEW_VERSION=$(apt-get -sqq upgrade | grep Inst | grep ${APP} | awk '{print $3}')
		NEW_VERSION=${GIT_VERSION}
		echo -e "\n${WARN}${G} Signal will be upgraded from ${Y}${CURRENT_VERSION} ${G}to ${Y}${NEW_VERSION}${N}"
		sudo apt-get -qq update
		sudo apt install ${APP}
		echo "${NEW_VERSION}" > ${LOCALDIR}/.version
	else
		echo -e "\n${OK}${Y} ${APP} ${G}is at it's latest version${N}\n"
	fi
}

#===============================================================================
#       Main Run
#===============================================================================

backup_local_signal # You can comment this out once everything is working
mount_gdrive
check_for_upgrade
compare_datestamp_and_sync
run_signal
#sleep 2
compare_datestamp_and_sync
unmount_gdrive

posts.name: Annalisa
posts.cooked:
cweinhofer:

I need to update from Win 10 to Win 11

Hi Herohtar! I also need to update from Win 10 to Win 11 and have read conflicting information in this thread on how to backup/restore my Signal Desktop data . What is the status as at Sept 2025 regarding how best to handle Signal Desktop data backup? Thank you.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
cweinhofer:

I am about to loose 3+ years of message history

You‚Äôre not. Moving to a new computer or restoring after a system wipe/clean install with the desktop app is as simple as copying a single folder (the Signal data folder).

On Windows 10, that folder is C:\Users\<YourName>\AppData\Roaming\Signal. Simply make a backup of that folder, do your system upgrade, reinstall Signal, then copy your backed up folder back in to place.

For completeness, the full list of folders for supported operating systems are:

macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/Signal
Linux: ~/.config/Signal
Windows 10: C:\Users\<YourName>\AppData\Roaming\Signal

They can all be used to backup/restore/transfer your Signal Desktop data in the same way.
